Dear Ms. Hargis:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
July 13, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all
of the
following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One of four closed case files reviewed did not have documentation of the name and
official title of the person to whom the youth was discharged to. There were two
discharge forms present in the file but neither had the name of the person and one
only had the title of “mom” documented.
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be
located on land that is properly drained.
Each of the bedrooms inspected (all bedrooms) had damaged screens on windows
that would open.
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(6) Plumbing fixtures and water and waste pipes shall be
properly installed and maintained in good working
condition.
Three of four working showers inspected had shower heads that were corroded and
in need of cleaning and repair.
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(7) Water closet compartments, bathroom, and kitchen
floors shall be constructed and maintained so as to be
reasonably impervious to water and be composed of a slip
resistant material.
1

One of two bathrooms inspected during this review had a floor that appeared to be
made of large vinyl squares. Several of these squares were loose.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) This facility does not have a DHS Contract, therefore Contract/Policy violation
does not apply.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
 Several of the forms used by the facility had missing information such as
signatures and dates. There were also general items missing which allowed
the form to look unfinished. This was discussed, along with the underlying
reasons that this was occurring. The facility was open to suggestions on
resolving this issue and understood that leaving sections of a form blank gives
the impression that it is not complete.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
 The facility shared that they now have an individual with the responsibility for
compliance. We discussed methods of developing a compliance process to
ensure that all forms are complete, and all youth records are kept in
compliance. It was suggested that they use the third shift staff to review forms
and case files but keep their primary focus on room checks and youth
supervision.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first submitted and approved corrective action plan involved special investigation
2021C0214009. The allegations involved the facility providing the wrong doze of
medication to a youth at the facility. After an in-depth investigation, the facility was
found to be in violation of Rule 400.4142 (Health services). The facility submitted a
corrective action plan which was approved on 5/14/2021. Within this CAP the facility
stated they would take the following actions:
2

 Update medication forms 915 & 915.5.
 Update medical consent waiver 510.
 Retrain staff on medication procedures.
 Use medical consent waiver for documentation of youth’s medication.
 Retrain staff on role of on-call admissions.
 Update behavior questionnaire.
 Two reviews of case file for completion of documents, using review case sheet.
 Update intake questionnaire.
 Retrain staff on modified intake assessments and new forms.
 All existing staff to complete yearly medication management training.
 Develop methods of recruitment of new staff.
Evidence provided by the facility indicates that they have completed parts of the CAP.
This includes the updating of the forms identified above. It was documented that staff
are still being trained with a plan to have this finished at the end of the month. They are
struggling to get staff to complete the review process as identified and this issue was
discussed during this inspection. The use of the 3rd shift staff to help in his effort will be
explored by the facility. They reported still being in the process of attempting to hire
more staff through the use of “job fairs”.
The second CAP was in regard to their 2020 Renewal Inspection.
An unannounced on-site visit took place on 2/9/21. Youth rooms was observed to be
generally clean and well supplied. The facility is an older building and could use repairs
to the windowsills and a fresh coat of paint. The milieu, kitchen, and bathroom areas
were observed and appeared to be also clean. The meal menu was posted. All cleaning
supplies and other chemical items were locked with no access available for the youth.
Youth were observed eating a meal and engaged in various activities in the milieu area.
An unannounced on-site visit took place on 6/4/21. Youth rooms was observed to be
generally clean and well supplied. The screens in the bedrooms are in need of repair
and the bathroom floor also needs repairs. The boy’s bathroom needs to be cleaned.
The milieu and kitchen areas were observed and appeared to be clean. The meal menu
was posted. All cleaning supplies and other chemical items were locked with no access
available for the youth. The youth present were engaged in different activities at the
time of this visit. The needed repairs were discussed with the staff and it was
recommended that repairs take place as soon as possible.
Interviews with staff and youth were conducted. The youth report feeling safe and well
cared for. They had no concerns other than the condition of the showerheads in the
bathroom which is identified above in the violation section of this report. They shared a
belief that the facility is meeting all of their needs and providing them support to make
the changes necessary in their lives. The report that staff are attentive to their needs.
Staff interviewed report a strong desire to provide best practice to the youth and believe
the administration is support of this goal. They did share a desire for more training on
how to help the youth and a need for more staff to be hired. Administration staff
3

interviewed also report a strong desire to provide best practice for youth and a healthy
environment for their staff.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
